bioghist.p: J.A.G. Rehn (1881-1965) was an entomologist at the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia. He first joined the Academy in 1900 as a student. He became curator of the insect collection in 1933 and continued in that role until his death in 1965. He was very active in the American Entomological Society, serving as the organization's president (1942-1946 and 1952-1953) and treasurer (1930-1959) as well as serving on several committees. He published extensively and was an expert on Orthoptera. He also participated in several of the Academy's expeditions, including those to Africa, Costa Rica, and Brazil.

scopecontent.p: This is a small collection of correspondence, notes, and photographs of J.A.G. Rehn. Materials include: professional correspondence (1904-1965) related to the exchange of specimens, arrangements for international collecting expeditions, taxonomy, and requests for the return of borrowed specimens; notes, possibly for a talk, entitled "Basic Faunistic Aspects of the Orthoptera of North America," and handwritten extracts from published materials on geology, and zoogeography; slides of landscapes, insects, and drawings of insects; photographs and negatives; and newspaper clippings about Rehn. The collection also includes African artifacts, including a bow, arrows and a quiver, textiles, and a length of rope. These items were presumably collection by Rehn on the George Vanderbilt Africa Expedition in 1934. The collection also contains records related to Rehnâ€™s father, William J. Rehn, including a discharge from the Grand Army of the Republic (1895), the D.C. Volunteers (1864), and the US Army (1865).

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
